data.title: Instagram to test hiding Like counts in the US next week
data.text: “We will make decisions that hurt the business if they help people’s well-being and health” says Instagram’s CEO Adam Mosseri.

data.title: Facebook apologizes after anonymous post alleges racism at company
data.text: The social media company has been accused of empowering "racism against its employees of color."

data.title: Facebook Says It’s Removing Mentions Of Potential Names Of Ukraine Whistleblower
data.text: Facebook said Friday that it will remove mentions that name the whistleblower who filed a complaint over President Donald Trump’s July 25 phone call with the president of Ukraine, triggering the current impeachment inquiry. “Any mention of the potential whistleblower’s name violates our coordinating harm policy, which prohibits content ‘outing of witness, informant, or activist,’

data.title: Top Facebook exec who left this year says political ads should be fact checked
data.text: In September, Facebook said that it will not fact check or remove content posted by politicians except with a few exceptions.

data.title: Facebook apologizes after employees complain about racist company culture
data.text: Facebook on Friday issued an apology following an anonymous blog post complaining about a racist culture toward black, Hispanic and female Asian employees at the social media company.

data.title: Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes doesn't recall Zuckerberg discussing the Iraq War at Harvard
data.text: Hughes said on Friday that Zuckerberg's claim that the Iraq War helped shape his views on free speech doesn't sound quite right.

data.title: Facebook co-founder: Allowing false political ads skirts 'responsibility to democracy'
data.text: Chris Hughes, who left Facebook in 2007, also said Mark Zuckerberg's claim Facebook was founded as a reaction to the Iraq war was "new to me."

data.title: Facebook says it is removing 'any and all mention of the potential whistleblower's name'
data.text: Facebook said Friday that it was removing content that mentioned any potential name of the whistleblower whose complaint sparked an impeachment probe into President Trump.

data.title: Facebook’s first experimental apps from its ‘NPE Team’ division focus on students, chat & music
data.text: This July, Facebook announced a new division called NPE Team which would build experimental consumer-facing apps, allowing the company to try out new ideas and features to see how people would react.

data.title: Facebook's plan to integrate Messenger, WhatsApp and Instagram might be tougher than it looks
data.text: WhatsApp co-founder Brian Acton called Facebook's efforts a "very tall order."

data.title: What's Revealed in Facebook's Leaked Documents
data.text: Nov.08 -- Leaked Facebook documents suggest business considerations outweigh privacy concerns.

data.title: Facebook will remove posts that name the Ukraine whistleblower
data.text: Facebook is taking down any content that seeks to unmask the Ukraine whistleblower from its platform.

data.title: Facebook, Google Considering Changes In Political Ad Policies
data.text: Facebook Inc. (NASDAQ: FB) and Alphabet Inc.'s (NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google are considering changing policies on political ads, weighing the costs of being in the middle of the debate over truth in political speech against the multibillion-dollar election-year opportunity.

data.title: 5 Stocks to Buy With Leadership From All-Star Management Teams
data.text: Behind every great stock is a great management team. These five stocks may have the best management teams out there.

data.title: Apple, Facebook, Google and Amazon are putting billions of dollars toward affordable housing — but that money may be too little, too late
data.text: Housing prices have skyrocketed in cities like San Francisco and Seattle, and tech companies are scrambling to ensure there’s an affordable place to live for their workforces.

data.title: Facebook, Alphabet are the most likely tech giants to face antitrust action next year, Cowen says
data.text: State probes into Google and Facebook "could be viewed as political grandstanding. We think that would be a mistake," the analysts wrote.
